17.text:
Gaurav Tiwari was one of India’s foremost
paranormal investigators.

26.text:
Having entered the field after sharing a house
with a poltergeist whilst training to be a

31.text:
commercial pilot in America, Tiwari was revered
for scientific method and his efforts at educating

40.text:
His interest and ability eventually led him
to found the Indian Paranormal Society.

47.text:
On the 7th of July 2016, Tiwari would conduct
his last ever paranormal investigation.

54.text:
Just a few hours after returning from an allegedly
haunted house, he passed away.

60.text:
Tiwari’s death has been shrouded in mystery
ever since his body was discovered with a

66.text: thin black line around his neck.

69.text: The initial official explanation was suicide.

72.text:
Yet, without a plausible motive and a concurring
medical report, the case was reclassified

80.text:
Certainly, in suicide cases where death is
by hanging, the trachea invariably ruptures.

86.text:
In the case of Tiwari, the black line around
his neck had done no such damage.

92.text:
In the months that have followed his sudden

101.text:

115.text:

120.text: is that one to two percent that is genuine.

Could he have found out that he was all too

129.text:
some paranormal forces have the power to cause

142.text:
In the summer of 2013, 25-year-old John Jenkin
from Cumbria, England expressed fears that

152.text:
Whilst in a deranged state, he approached
a van driver, put his hands in the air in

157.text:
a ‘surrender’ motion and cried out: “I
am armed, but it’s not in my hands.”

165.text:
Desperate to avoid committing such an atrocity,
Jenkin tried to end his life by drowning himself

172.text:
He was discovered later that day, unstable,

179.text:
After his failed suicide attempt, Jenkin was

184.text:
However, staff judged him as low risk and

189.text:
Later that evening, he confessed to a group
of friends that he was “possessed by demons”.

194.text:
He also said: “I am the devil, I need to
confess.”

200.text:
The following morning, Jenkin butchered his
mother and sister with an axe.

206.text:
After the killings, Jenkin was found naked
crouched behind a bench, acting erratically.

212.text:
When a police officer asked him if he had
taken anything, Jenkin replied: “Lives.”

216.text:
The ensuing inquest into the murders revealed
that on the night prior to Jenkin’s barbaric

225.text:
rampage, his sister, Katie, had confided in
a friend that she was “really worried”

231.text:
She expressed fears that “he didn’t seem
like her brother and he didn’t look like

235.text:
her brother any more”.
“... he was not really talkative … when

240.text:
he was looking at her it was not John’s
eyes, it was almost as if it was someone else.”

246.text:
If a pregnant woman dies in Malaysia it is
imperative that the following ritual is performed

260.text:
The dead woman's mouth must be filled with
glass beads and a single needle should be

265.text: placed in each of her hands.

269.text:
If this does not happen, then she may return
from the dead in the form of one of the most

274.text: malevolent beings of folklore - a Pontianak.

279.text:
The Pontianak is vampiric in nature and has
many tactics for quenching its thirst for

286.text:
Sometimes it will mimic the sound of a baby
crying in the hope that a passer-by will be

291.text:
tricked into straying from the safety of the
path to investigate.

294.text:
The softer the baby’s cry, the closer the
Pontianak is to you.

300.text:
It is also said that the Pontianak will use
its appearance in order to hunt its prey.

307.text:
As this creature often takes the form of a
young, beautiful woman, it will use this beauty

312.text: to lure men to isolated locations.

315.text:
However, once alone her alluring gaze changes
and her once sweet floral scent transforms

324.text: At once, the man is attacked.

327.text:
The savage spirit digs in its sharp fingernails;
the victim's abdomen is ripped open.

333.text:
What follows is a blood-bath: the Pontianak
will gorge itself on the man's blood and innards

340.text:
The monster may even brutally castrate its
victim, prolonging the pain for its own delight.

347.text:
However, the Pontianak is feared above all
else for its love of newborn children.

354.text:
The blood of a woman in labour is believed
to draw in this terrifying creature, meaning

359.text:
that even today in Malaysia it is customary
to bury the umbilical cord and blood stained

364.text: clothes of a woman after giving birth.

368.text:
In order to break the Pontianak’s cycle
of slaughter, it is said that a nail must

373.text: be driven into the back of its neck.

376.text:
So long as the nail remains, the blood drive
is destroyed and the Pontianak will become

521.text:
According to modern knowledge, there is only
one specimen of Satanic calligraphy in existence.

526.text:
This curious extract first appeared in 1523,
taken from an Italian text which describes

534.text:
an encounter between Ludovico Spoletano and
the Devil.

538.text:
Spoletano allegedly summoned Satan, requesting
that he use his body as a vessel to write

544.text:
clear and legible answers to a series of questions
asked of him.

548.text:
However, the King of Hell refused to cooperate,
and instead snatched the pen into midair so

553.text: as to rapidly scrawl the answers himself.

556.text:
What the Devil wrote was indecipherable: a
series of diabolic scrawls that seems as though

561.text: it should read from left to right.

565.text:
After being passed onto several learned men
without success of decryption, the text disappeared

572.text:
As of today, no one has been able to decode

578.text:
However, academics have identified traces

584.text:
Amharic, a language spoken in its purity in

590.text:
According to legend, this was the primeval

609.text:
La Voisin, a French fortune teller, poisoner
and professed sorceress, was known to have

615.text:
killed anywhere between 1000 to 2,500 people
in Black Masses.

625.text:
The richest and brightest stars of the French
court would visit the notorious fortune teller

631.text:
to request that she whisper in the Devil’s
ear on their behalf.

636.text:
One example was Madame de Montespan who employed
la Voisin to conduct multiple Black Masses

642.text:
in order to secure the love of the King of
France.

646.text:
Within one year, Montespan was Louis 14th’s
(XIV) official royal mistress.

651.text:
La Voisin’s Black Mass made use of a naked
female human alter, in mockery of the sacredness

661.text:
The woman would lie naked with a chalice on

667.text: in each of her outstretched arms.

670.text:
Such an aspect would become a permanent feature

677.text:
The power of blood was also an important feature
of the Black Mass.

681.text:
La Voisin would have many children abducted
to be sacrificed.

An attendant of la Voisin was discovered to

702.text:
A long black velvet pall was spread over the

714.text:
Six black candles were lit [...] the gold
paten and chalice were placed upon the naked

719.text:

732.text:
The child was held over the altar, a sharp

739.text:

744.text:
The corpse was handed to la Voisin, who flung

750.text: purpose which glowed white-hot in its fierceness.

755.text:
Although la Voisin met a grisly fate upon

770.text:
Mitar Tarabić was an illiterate peasant from
the small Serbian village of Kremna.

777.text:
Before his death in 1899, he acquired a local
reputation for his apparent ability to see

786.text:
The local Orthodox priest at the time decided
to write down his predictions for posterity.

792.text:
These passages are now referred to as the
Prophecies of Kremna.

797.text:
Unlike many acclaimed seers, Tarabić’s
prophecies contain a surprising amount of

803.text:
detail, including specific names, places and
dates.

807.text:
In one of his predictions, he is recorded
as having said:

811.text:
"After the assassination of the King and Queen,
the Karađorđevićs will come to power.

817.text: Then we will again start a war with the Turks.

819.text:
Four Christian states will attack Turkey,
and our border will be on the river Lim.

825.text: Then we shall finally conquer and avenge Kosovo..."

830.text:
From 1903 to 1912, Tarabić’s prophecy played
out perfectly: the Serbian King and Queen

838.text:
were killed by their own guards, and replaced
by the Karađorđević dynasty.

843.text:
Shortly afterwards, the First Balkan War broke
out, which saw four Christian nations - [Serbia,

849.text:
Bulgaria, Greece and Montenegro ]- fight against
the Ottoman empire.

851.text:
The result was the successful expansion of
Serbia to the river Lim.

858.text:
During this conversation with the local priest,
Tarabić offered startling insight into another

865.text:
"Soon after this war, another war will start...the
Big War in which a lot of blood will be spilled.

873.text:
If that blood were a river, a huge stone of
300 kilograms would roll in its current easily…

880.text:
I will tell you one more thing, father: the
invading army will come to Kremna exactly

886.text:
on your baptismal day, stay for three years
and go away on the same day they came—St

893.text: But you will not see the end of the war.

896.text:
In the last year of the world’s big carnage,
you will die.

901.text:
Both these wars, the one with the Turks and
the big one when the whole world will be at

905.text:
war, will take away two of your grandchildren—one
before, and the other after your death."

913.text: Once again, Tarabić’s words became reality.

918.text:
During World War One, the Serbian army was
defeated by the Germans on 9th October, making

924.text:
it highly probable that the village of Krenma
was occupied a few days later, on St Luke's

932.text:
Serbia was liberated three years later, one
again around St Luke's day.

938.text:
Tarabić’s priest died in 1918, the final
year of World War One, having survived one

944.text: his grandchildren, who died during the bloodshed.

947.text:
His other grandchild outlived him, but would
later die in World War Two.

953.text:
Tarabić would go on to reveal many more accurate
predictions of the future, making allusions

960.text:
to a ‘red czar upon the Russian throne’
who will not wage war until attacked.

967.text:
Stalin only entered World War Two after being
attacked by Hitler.

971.text:
Tarabić also described the ‘great kingdoms
from across the sea’ who would set free

979.text:
In regards to more modern times, he is claimed
to have stated that:

983.text:
"Men will build a box and within will be some
kind of gadget with images, but they will

989.text:
not be able to communicate with me already
dead, even though this image gadget will be

994.text:
as close to this other world as hairs on the
human scalp are close to each other.

1000.text:
With the help of this image gadget, man will
be able to see everything that is happening

1006.text:
Although Tarabić died long before the rise
of television and computers, he seemed to

1012.text:
possess an insight into the technological
advancements of a future society.

1018.text: Elaborating on this trend, he described how:

1021.text:
“The more people will know, the less they
will love and care for each other.

1026.text:
Hatred will be so great between them that
they will care more for their different gadgets

1031.text:
than for their relatives...Man will trust
his gadget more than his first neighbour…’’

1042.text:
However, at least one author has questioned

1048.text:
suggesting that the Mitar Tarabić is little
more than a local legend.

1053.text:
Yet, it could be that those who question the

1059.text:

1082.text:
When this horrible war starts, woe to those
armies that fly over skies; better off will

be those who fight on ground and water [...] Then
people will run away from cities to the country

1350.text:
Rather, there is a government bureau which

1372.text:
